sen.j: 武家茶道（ぶけさどう）とは、おもに江戸時代以降に武家社会の間で行われてきた茶道のこと。
sen.e: Buke sado is the tea ceremony performed among the samurai families mainly in the Edo period and after.

sen.j: 多くの場合、各藩各大名でそれぞれ公式の流儀が定められており、一つの領国内のみで行われていた流儀も多い。
sen.e: Often each clan or daimyo had its own formal mode of the tea ceremony, and many of such modes were only performed within each particular fief.
Often each clan or daimyo had its own style of tea ceremony, and many of such styles were only performed in each fief.
sen.cmt: 「流儀」の訳を変更within each particular fief→in each fiefに変更
sen.e: Often each clan or daimyo had its own style of tea ceremony, and many of such styles were only performed in each fief.

sen.j: 江戸時代から家元制度をとっていた町人茶と違い、武家茶道においてはいわば各藩の殿様が家元に相当する立場である。
sen.e: Unlike the merchant class tea ceremony of the Edo period in which iemoto (the head of a tea ceremony school) system was established, the lord of each clan was, as it were, the head of each school in buke sado.

sen.j: 実務は茶道師範に任せていることが大半であるが、中には大名自ら深く茶道を嗜んでいる事例もある。
sen.e: Although the practical management of the tea ceremony was assigned to a tea ceremony instructor in most cases, there were some examples where the lord himself had profound knowledge of the tea ceremony.

sen.j: 主な流儀に遠州流、石州流、有楽流、上田宗箇流、鎮信流、不昧流、小笠原家茶道古流、御家流 (茶道)などがある。
sen.e: Major schools of buke sado include Enshu-ryu, Sekishu-ryu, Uraku-ryu, Uedasoko-ryu, Chinshin-ryu, Fumai-ryu, Ogasawarake-sado-koryu, and Oie-ryu (of tea ceremony).
sen.cmt: 通常流派名は「XX流」を"XX School"と訳すので-ryuを残すと重複表現になるかと危惧しました。しかし、特に「小笠原家茶道古流」を表現するのにryuを残すほうが自然なので、そのような選択をしました。

sen.j: 将軍家茶道師範役だった片桐石州の石州流は、とくに多くの分派を持ち、武家社会に浸透していた。
sen.e: Founded by Sekishu KATAGIRI who was the tea ceremony teacher for the Shogun family, Sekishu school had particularly a large number of sects and permeated throughout the samurai society.

sen.j: 廃藩置県以降、武家社会の崩壊とともに消滅した流儀も多いといわれる。
sen.e: Many schools are said to have disappeared along with the collapse of the samurai society following Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).
